title: A Spectrum of Approximate Probabilistic Bisimulations

We start with the seminal notion of Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimulations of Desharnais et al. . While originally introduced for labeled Markov processes  , Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimulations were later adapted to other models like LMCs 4 [ref]38 or Segalaâ€™s probabilistic automata  . A reflexive111In contrast to  4 we require reflexivity of Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimulations. LMCs â„³,ğ’©â„³ğ’©\mathcal{M},\mathcal{N} are Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimilar, denoted â„³âˆ¼Îµğ’©subscriptsimilar-toğœ€â„³ğ’©\mathcal{M}\sim_{\varepsilon}\mathcal{N}, if siâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹tâ„³âˆ¼Îµsiâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹tğ’©subscriptsimilar-toğœ€superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡â„³superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ’©s_{init}^{\mathcal{M}}\sim_{\varepsilon}s_{init}^{\mathcal{N}} in â„³âŠ•ğ’©direct-sumâ„³ğ’©\mathcal{M}\oplus\mathcal{N}. Intuitively, sâˆ¼Îµtsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\sim_{\varepsilon}t if both states can mimic the otherâ€™s transition probabilities to any AâŠ†Sğ´ğ‘†A\subseteq S by transitioning to the (potentially bigger) set âˆ¼Îµ(A)subscriptsimilar-toğœ€absentğ´{\sim_{\varepsilon}}(A) with a probability that is smaller by at most Îµğœ€\varepsilon than the original one. The parameter Îµğœ€\varepsilon describes how much the behavior of related states may differ: for Îµğœ€\varepsilon close to 111 more states can be related, while for Îµâ‰ˆ0ğœ€0\varepsilon\approx 0 related states behave almost equivalently. In the extreme case of Îµ=0ğœ€0\varepsilon=0, we have âˆ¼0â£=â£âˆ¼subscriptsimilar-to0similar-to{\sim_{0}}={\sim}  4. Instead of being transitive, Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimulations are additive in their tolerances: sâˆ¼Îµ1tsubscriptsimilar-tosubscriptğœ€1ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\sim_{\varepsilon_{1}}t and tâˆ¼Îµ2usubscriptsimilar-tosubscriptğœ€2ğ‘¡ğ‘¢t\sim_{\varepsilon_{2}}u implies sâˆ¼Îµâ€²usubscriptsimilar-tosuperscriptğœ€â€²ğ‘ ğ‘¢s\sim_{\varepsilon^{\prime}}u for some 0â‰¤Îµâ€²â‰¤minâ¡{1,Îµ1+Îµ2}0superscriptğœ€â€²1subscriptğœ€1subscriptğœ€20\leq\varepsilon^{\prime}\leq\min\{1,\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2}\} .
As the next example suggests, transitivity is not always desirable for Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimulations if Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0. Let Îµ=1nğœ€1ğ‘›\varepsilon=\frac{1}{n} for nâ‰¥1ğ‘›1n\geq 1 and consider the LMC of FigureÂ 2. Hence, s0subscriptğ‘ 0s_{0} and snsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›s_{n} are related by a chain of Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimilar states, even though they behave completely different: s0subscriptğ‘ 0s_{0} transitions to the {a}ğ‘\{a\}-labeled state xğ‘¥x with probability 00, snsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›s_{n} does so with probability 111. There are different ways to characterize Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimulations. For example, Desharnais et al.Â  provide a characterization in terms of the values of maximum flows in specific flow networks. Their result is well-suited for algorithmic purposes, but is restricted to finite models. Another way to express condition (ii) of DefinitionÂ 3.1 is via the existence of weight functions Î”:Sâ†’Dâ€‹iâ€‹sâ€‹tâ€‹râ€‹(S):Î”â†’ğ‘†ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘†\Delta\colon S\to Distr(S) that describe how to split the successor probabilities of related states. This approach is used in, e.g.,  [ref]38  [ref]31. The following lemma describes one possible way to define such weight functions in order to characterize Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimulations. A reflexive and symmetric relation RâŠ†SÃ—Sğ‘…ğ‘†ğ‘†R\subseteq S\times S that only relates states with the same label is an Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimulation iff for all (s,t)âˆˆRğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘…(s,t)\in R there is a map Î”:ğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘â€‹(s)â†’ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿâ€‹(ğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘â€‹(t)):Î”â†’ğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡\Delta\colon\mathit{Succ}(s)\to\mathit{Distr}(\mathit{Succ}(t)) such that for all tâ€²âˆˆğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘â€‹(t)superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡t^{\prime}\in\mathit{Succ}(t) we have , and âˆ‘sâ€²âˆˆğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘â€‹(s)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ \sum_{s^{\prime}\in\mathit{Succ}(s)}. More precisely, it shows that (i) if we move from sğ‘ s to a successor sâ€²superscriptğ‘ â€²s^{\prime} with probability  and, afterwards, from sâ€²superscriptğ‘ â€²s^{\prime} to a successor tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime} of tğ‘¡t with probability Î”â€‹(sâ€²)â€‹(tâ€²)Î”superscriptğ‘ â€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²\Delta(s^{\prime})(t^{\prime}), then we reach tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime} with probability , and that (ii) the overall probability that the states sâ€²superscriptğ‘ â€²s^{\prime} and tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime} are Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimilar is at least 1âˆ’Îµ1ğœ€1-\varepsilon. A second notion of approximate probabilistic bisimulation are Îµğœ€\varepsilon-APBs, which stands short for approximate probabilistic bisimulations with precision Îµğœ€\varepsilon   . In contrast to Îµğœ€\varepsilon-bisimulations, where the differences in transition probabilities of related states are bounded w.r.t. all subsets AâŠ†Sğ´ğ‘†A\subseteq S, an Îµğœ€\varepsilon-APB Rğ‘…R only requires a difference of at most Îµğœ€\varepsilon for the probabilities of related states to transition to Rğ‘…R-closed subsets of Sğ‘†S. A reflexive and symmetric relation RâŠ†SÃ—Sğ‘…ğ‘†ğ‘†R\subseteq S\times S is an Îµğœ€\varepsilon-APB if for all (s,t)âˆˆRğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘…(s,t)\in R and any Rğ‘…R-closed set AâŠ†Sğ´ğ‘†A\subseteq S it holds that We write sâ‰¡Îµtsubscriptğœ€ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\equiv_{\varepsilon}t if sğ‘ s and tğ‘¡t are related by any Îµğœ€\varepsilon-APB, and â„³â‰¡Îµğ’©subscriptğœ€â„³ğ’©\mathcal{M}\equiv_{\varepsilon}\mathcal{N} if siâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹tâ„³â‰¡Îµsiâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹tğ’©subscriptğœ€superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡â„³superscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ’©s_{init}^{\mathcal{M}}\equiv_{\varepsilon}s_{init}^{\mathcal{N}} in â„³âŠ•ğ’©direct-sumâ„³ğ’©\mathcal{M}\oplus\mathcal{N}. Let Îµâˆˆ(0,1]ğœ€01\varepsilon\in(0,1] and n=âŒˆ1ÎµâŒ‰âˆˆâ„•ğ‘›1ğœ€â„•n=\left\lceil\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right\rceil\in\mathbb{N}. Consider â„³â„³\mathcal{M} as in FigureÂ 3, and let Rğ‘…R be the reflexive and symmetric closure of {(s,t),(x,x),(y,y)}âˆª{(ui,ui+1)âˆ£0â‰¤iâ‰¤nâˆ’1}ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¦conditional-setsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–10ğ‘–ğ‘›1\{(s,t),(x,x),(y,y)\}\cup\{(u_{i},u_{i+1})\mid 0\leq i\leq n-1\}.

so Rğ‘…R is an Îµğœ€\varepsilon-APB. ExampleÂ 3.5 illustrates that the use of Îµğœ€\varepsilon-APBs as a notion that relates states with almost equivalent behavior is questionable: even though states sğ‘ s and tğ‘¡t in FigureÂ 3 are related by â‰¡Îµsubscriptğœ€\equiv_{\varepsilon}, they behave completely different. This is caused by the set {u0,â€¦,un}subscriptğ‘¢0â€¦subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘›\{u_{0},\dots,u_{n}\} of (unreachable) states being Rğ‘…R-closed, which in turn allows to relate sğ‘ s and tğ‘¡t by the relation Rğ‘…R from the example. Such an anomaly cannot occur for âˆ¼Îµsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€\sim_{\varepsilon}, and we in fact have sâ‰Îµtsubscriptnot-similar-toğœ€ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\nsim_{\varepsilon}t in FigureÂ 3 for every Îµâˆˆ(0,1)ğœ€01\varepsilon\in(0,1). In particular, this shows that âˆ¼Îµsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€\sim_{\varepsilon} can be strictly finer than â‰¡Îµsubscriptğœ€\equiv_{\varepsilon} for Îµâˆˆ(0,1)ğœ€01\varepsilon\in(0,1). Lastly, we introduce up-to-(n,Îµ)ğ‘›ğœ€(n,\varepsilon)-bisimulations  3, which are relations that require the behaviors of related states to differ by at most Îµğœ€\varepsilon for at least nğ‘›n steps. The up-to-(n,Îµ)ğ‘›ğœ€(n,\varepsilon)-bisimulation âˆ¼ÎµnâŠ†SÃ—S{\sim_{\varepsilon}^{n}}\subseteq S\times S is inductively defined on nğ‘›n via sâˆ¼Îµ0tsuperscriptsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€0ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\sim_{\varepsilon}^{0}t for all s,tâˆˆSğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘†s,t\in S and, for nâ‰¥0ğ‘›0n\geq 0, sâˆ¼Îµn+1tsuperscriptsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€ğ‘›1ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\sim_{\varepsilon}^{n+1}t iff for all AâŠ†Sğ´ğ‘†A\subseteq S States s,tğ‘ ğ‘¡s,t are (n,Îµ)ğ‘›ğœ€(n,\varepsilon)-bisimilar if sâˆ¼Îµntsuperscriptsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€ğ‘›ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\sim_{\varepsilon}^{n}t, and the notion is lifted to LMCs as usual. Similar to âˆ¼Îµsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€\sim_{\varepsilon} and â‰¡Îµsubscriptğœ€\equiv_{\varepsilon}, âˆ¼Îµnsuperscriptsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€ğ‘›\sim_{\varepsilon}^{n} is reflexive and symmetric, but not transitive. Instead, it is additive in the tolerances and monotonic in nğ‘›n and Îµğœ€\varepsilon, i.e., for nâ‰¥nâ€²ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›â€²n\geq n^{\prime} and Îµâ‰¤Îµâ€²ğœ€superscriptğœ€â€²\varepsilon\leq\varepsilon^{\prime}, sâˆ¼Îµntsuperscriptsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€ğ‘›ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\sim_{\varepsilon}^{n}t implies sâˆ¼Îµâ€²nâ€²tsuperscriptsubscriptsimilar-tosuperscriptğœ€â€²superscriptğ‘›â€²ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\sim_{\varepsilon^{\prime}}^{n^{\prime}}t 3. It is clear that sâˆ¼Îµntsuperscriptsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€ğ‘›ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\sim_{\varepsilon}^{n}t for a fixed nğ‘›n does not necessarily imply sâˆ¼Îµtsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\sim_{\varepsilon}t or sâ‰¡Îµtsubscriptğœ€ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\equiv_{\varepsilon}t, as (n,Îµ)ğ‘›ğœ€(n,\varepsilon)-bisimilarity only restricts the behavior of related states for nğ‘›n steps. However, considering the limit nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\to\infty makes âˆ¼Îµsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€\sim_{\varepsilon} and âˆ¼Îµnsuperscriptsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€ğ‘›\sim_{\varepsilon}^{n} coincide, i.e., sâˆ¼Îµtsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\sim_{\varepsilon}t iff sâˆ¼Îµntsuperscriptsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€ğ‘›ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\sim_{\varepsilon}^{n}t for all nâˆˆâ„•ğ‘›â„•n\in\mathbb{N} . We now make precise the relationship between Îµğœ€\varepsilon-APBs and up-to-(n,Îµ)ğ‘›ğœ€(n,\varepsilon)-bisimulations. If Îµâˆˆ(0,1)ğœ€01\varepsilon\in(0,1), sâ‰¡Îµtsubscriptğœ€ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\equiv_{\varepsilon}t implies sâˆ¼Îµntsuperscriptsubscriptsimilar-toğœ€ğ‘›ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\sim_{\varepsilon}^{n}t if nâ‰¤2ğ‘›2n\leq 2, but not necessarily if nâ‰¥3ğ‘›3n\geq 3.
